The poem was composed in a grass hut in Champahatti, Navadwipa, north of what is now Kolkata, after Jayadeva turned his back on the sumptuous surroundings of the Bengal court. It came into existence in July 1982 and covers an area of approximately 200 square kilometres (77 sq mi). The park extends from the Teerathagarh waterfalls in the west to the Kolab river ( Odisha state boundary) in the east, spanning an average length of 33.5 km (20.8 mi) and an average width of 6 km (3.7 mi) from north to south. It derives its name from the Kanger river, which flows centrally through it.
